An Honorable Code?
By CHRIS OHLY
The aim of "liberal democracy" is the
guarantee to all societal members of certain
inalienable rights, among these the right of
self determination and
the right of
protection from arbitrary rule.
The espoused aims of the Gordon-Benton
conduct code are as noble. The conduct code
proclaims a "traditional dependence on self
discipline" based upon "rational inquiry and
dialogue" that is the mark of an "association
of scholars." We are told that the code, in its
formulation and application, must be
"mindful of the interests and rights of its
members, must uphold the right of free
speech, and must not betray its humane
tradition."
But this noble rhetoric is fraudulent, and
betrays the hypocrisy of the Gordon-Benton
administration.
Punitive Code
After nearly eighteen months' debate over
the institution of a judicial mechanism and
code of conduct, designed mainly to protect
the student from arbitrary administrative
decisions of punitive nature, "rational
inquiry and dialogue" has been abandoned
by the administration.
With the promulgation of the GordonBenton code on September 1, the administration has made clear its intention to
ignore the fruits of debate in representative
institutions. After the ad-hoc committee's
report on conduct of May 29, 1969 (an ad-hoc
committee appointed by the President), and
after more debate in the Student Affairs
Committee,from September 1969 to January
1970, and even after the President's carefully
thought out modifications of March 31, we
still are faced with a new code.
This code, is "based on a special report ...
from the Committee on Governance," (It is
interesting to note that only one of three
undergraduate members of that Committee
has signed his name to that document.)
This code was prepared by the Dean,
however, and seemingly, given to the
Committee on Governance for its stamp of
approval. There is no more inquiry or
dialogue. Only the words of the Dean.
The words of the Dean, are indeed, clearly
oriented towards ensuring the University's
"integrity as a social institution," rather
than protecting the "interests and rights of
its members," It is curious that every one of
the listed "obvious forms of misconduct" is
designed to protect either University
facilities, or its "effective functioning."
It is also curious that each of these items
could be taken as a negation of some activity
taken by some members of this "association
of scholars" in last year's disturbances.
Does the University uphold its "humane
tradition" by implementing a code that
values property more than it values the
rights of its members? The University is not
the buildings that make up the campus. It is
not even the work that goes on within those
buildings.
Protect People
The University is the people who live
together in those buildings. Thus to preserve
its "integrity as a social institution" the
administration should think of protecting
people and not bricks and boards ... lest
those bricks and boards become used by
people to secure protection.

It should think of protecting the "interests
and rights" of individuals and not institutions ... lest those individuals abandon
old, repressive institutions for ones created
by themselves which serve their individual
interests, rather than self-serving institutional ones. These are by no means
meant to be threatening statements, merely
general observations.
Repression breeds violence, whether that
repression is administered on a nationwide
scale (as by the Nixon-Agnew-Mitchell
administration in Washington), or by private
institutions.
Administration Hypocrisy
I suggest that the University's administration is hypocritical when it claims to
be "liberal democratic" in its orientation,
and denies the right of self-discipline and
self-rule to students. I suggest that it is
hypocritical when it makes this claim, and
denies the fruits of its representative institutions' rational inquiry.
It is hypocritical when it claims a
"humane tradition" and a desire to "uphold
free speech," and then denies "the
unauthorized use of sound amplification
equipment," or "holding demonstrations
which disrupt regular or essential" activity,
without defining what regular or essential
activity is.
It is hypocritical when it claims to protect
the student from arbitrariness of administration, and then gives itself special
emergency powers in which the Dean can
invoke immediate penalties, call in civil
authority, or "use other suitable procedures
as the situation requires," when the Dean
decides that an emergency situation exists.
Students can do little about hypocrisy as
such ... at least now. We can do little now but
treat such situations as isolated aberrations,
though we may see them as endemic in
University policy. What then can we as
students do to encourage this private institution to recognize our rights? Private
institutions legally are not bound to give due
process, and except for vagarity, the code
itself is legally a satisfactory document.
Unsatisfactory
Nonetheless, it remains unsatisfactory to
students, because it fails to recognize our
Infringement upon
fundemental rights.
those rights is dangerous not only because of
our immediate concern, but because it
makes the University as an institution
complicit with, and non-neutral with regard
to, the repression of rights and just protest
now beginning to appear in the larger
society.
The application of incrementally increasing pressure on the administration,
seems for the time being, our only recourse.
We must organize ourselves, and elicit
support from all members of the community
who share in our outrage. We should
familiarize ourselves with all the issues
involved, to be able to engage in the
"rational inquiry and dialogue" that the
University administration claims as our
tradition.
And if the administration continues in
stubbornness to abandon that method, we
can only look forward to further, expanded
strife within the University.
Chris Ohly is a member of the Student Council

An Honorable Code?
By CHRIS OHLY
The aim of "liberal democracy" is the
guarantee to all societal members of certain
inalienable rights, among these the right of
self determination and
the right of
protection from arbitrary rule.
The espoused aims of the Gordon-Benton
conduct code are as noble. The conduct code
proclaims a "traditional dependence on self
discipline" based upon "rational inquiry and
dialogue" that is the mark of an "association
of scholars." We are told that the code, in its
formulation and application, must be
"mindful of the interests and rights of its
members, must uphold the right of free
speech, and must not betray its humane
tradition."
But this noble rhetoric is fraudulent, and
betrays the hypocrisy of the Gordon-Benton
administration.
Punitive Code
After nearly eighteen months' debate over
the institution of a judicial mechanism and
code of conduct, designed mainly to protect
the student from arbitrary administrative
decisions of punitive nature, "rational
inquiry and dialogue" has been abandoned
by the administration.
With the promulgation of the GordonBenton code on September 1, the administration has made clear its intention to
ignore the fruits of debate in representative
institutions. After the ad-hoc committee's
report on conduct of May 29, 1969 (an ad-hoc
committee appointed by the President), and
after more debate in the Student Affairs
Committee,from September 1969 to January
1970, and even after the President's carefully
thought out modifications of March 31, we
still are faced with a new code.
This code, is "based on a special report ...
from the Committee on Governance," (It is
interesting to note that only one of three
undergraduate members of that Committee
has signed his name to that document.)
This code was prepared by the Dean,
however, and seemingly, given to the
Committee on Governance for its stamp of
approval. There is no more inquiry or
dialogue. Only the words of the Dean.
The words of the Dean, are indeed, clearly
oriented towards ensuring the University's
"integrity as a social institution," rather
than protecting the "interests and rights of
its members," It is curious that every one of
the listed "obvious forms of misconduct" is
designed to protect either University
facilities, or its "effective functioning."
It is also curious that each of these items
could be taken as a negation of some activity
taken by some members of this "association
of scholars" in last year's disturbances.
Does the University uphold its "humane
tradition" by implementing a code that
values property more than it values the
rights of its members? The University is not
the buildings that make up the campus. It is
not even the work that goes on within those
buildings.
Protect People
The University is the people who live
together in those buildings. Thus to preserve
its "integrity as a social institution" the
administration should think of protecting
people and not bricks and boards ... lest
those bricks and boards become used by
people to secure protection.

It should think of protecting the "interests
and rights" of individuals and not institutions ... lest those individuals abandon
old, repressive institutions for ones created
by themselves which serve their individual
interests, rather than self-serving institutional ones. These are by no means
meant to be threatening statements, merely
general observations.
Repression breeds violence, whether that
repression is administered on a nationwide
scale (as by the Nixon-Agnew-Mitchell
administration in Washington), or by private
institutions.
Administration Hypocrisy
I suggest that the University's administration is hypocritical when it claims to
be "liberal democratic" in its orientation,
and denies the right of self-discipline and
self-rule to students. I suggest that it is
hypocritical when it makes this claim, and
denies the fruits of its representative institutions' rational inquiry.
It is hypocritical when it claims a
"humane tradition" and a desire to "uphold
free speech," and then denies "the
unauthorized use of sound amplification
equipment," or "holding demonstrations
which disrupt regular or essential" activity,
without defining what regular or essential
activity is.
It is hypocritical when it claims to protect
the student from arbitrariness of administration, and then gives itself special
emergency powers in which the Dean can
invoke immediate penalties, call in civil
authority, or "use other suitable procedures
as the situation requires," when the Dean
decides that an emergency situation exists.
Students can do little about hypocrisy as
such ... at least now. We can do little now but
treat such situations as isolated aberrations,
though we may see them as endemic in
University policy. What then can we as
students do to encourage this private institution to recognize our rights? Private
institutions legally are not bound to give due
process, and except for vagarity, the code
itself is legally a satisfactory document.
Unsatisfactory
Nonetheless, it remains unsatisfactory to
students, because it fails to recognize our
Infringement upon
fundemental rights.
those rights is dangerous not only because of
our immediate concern, but because it
makes the University as an institution
complicit with, and non-neutral with regard
to, the repression of rights and just protest
now beginning to appear in the larger
society.
The application of incrementally increasing pressure on the administration,
seems for the time being, our only recourse.
We must organize ourselves, and elicit
support from all members of the community
who share in our outrage. We should
familiarize ourselves with all the issues
involved, to be able to engage in the
"rational inquiry and dialogue" that the
University administration claims as our
tradition.
And if the administration continues in
stubbornness to abandon that method, we
can only look forward to further, expanded
strife within the University.
